div.p: always flying for a particular season near the shore – to where the nations bordering on the Seas resort to traffic their Peltries the principal Trade carried on is Carcajoux, Foxes & Sheep Skins for which they get dags Knives, awls, & beads[.] The dags are Shaped like a Sergeants halbert & the Iron very white & very Soft[.] [T]he natives here do not like them – but the beads are handsome in return[.] [T]hese are of the Colours, make & Shape as those got from the new discovered Indians of the Rocky Mountain in Peace River[.] These I believe is yankee Traders[.] When The Big Chief seperated from the Embay-o-dinnais the latter told him that they were going to pass the Summer & winter at a large river on the other side of the RocKy Mountain where they say there is a great deal of Br & plenty of all Kinds of animals, upon this River they intend to work Beaver all the Fall & come with it to the same Place where they met the Grand Chefre this spring, The ensuing season[.] The Former is of opinion that if they were sent with 2 or 3 Canadians in quest of this Tribe in the Fall, that they might be discovered perhaps at no considerable distance[.] Tho' he does not offer himself as a conductor – but speaks of it as a thing very possible, as there are many of the young men who would be very willing to go[.] [A]ll this may probably be very true but I suspect that the old fellow is wishing to flatter me out something Sans desein I Know him to well to confide in all what he tells me[.] I however gave him an old Shirt of my own & 4 Quarts of mixt rum[.] Paid him for having fed Jollibois all winter 10 Skins in Amn[.] [O]ne of the young men who came to day is from a band of about 16 Men who generally reside about porcupine Lake, as I have long been waiting for them, I asked this fellow where they were & why they did not come to the Fort – with their Credits[.] He told me that the Red Knives with mauvais Loup at their head had
